awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Towards a Theory for Sustainable Product Design
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this EArly-concept Research Grant (EAGER) project is to collect a comprehensive set of fundamental sustainable design principles that will, for the first time, combine existing international sustainable design standards and analytical quantitative models for sustainable design decisions, in order to advance sustainable design theory. With this information, an extensive database of sustainability knowledge will be developed from which novel quantitative metrics can be derived that connect design attributes to sustainability impact. The end result will address sustainable manufacturing and product development needs. 

If successful, this work will give researchers and product developers essential insight into the sustainability of early phase engineering designs by means of a transparent, cohesive system analysis that can be used during the early design phase, leading to a greater dissemination of environmentally friendly design and the availability of more sustainable products in the marketplace. The work will enable designers to better understand sustainable design in both quantitative and qualitative terms, determine ways to manufacture increasingly sustainable products, and communicate sustainability across the supply chain in a standardized way. Giving developers the tools to measure the sustainability of a potential product from the early design phase will facilitate the development of countless new sustainable products, reducing the global environmental impact of product manufacturing, use, and disposal.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research is to create a preliminary framework for understanding the environmental impact of products throughout the conceptual design phase. Currently, most methods that help engineering designers understand product environmental impact are performed retrospectively, sometimes years after design decisions are made and implemented. A new theory for sustainable product design was proposed and tested, which sought to move the understanding of environmental impact from being an after-the-fact analysis to an upfront approximation based on specific design attributes.

First, an extensive database of sustainable design knowledge was developed, including sustainable design guidelines, international design and manufacturing standards, product consumption data, consumer preference information, and product cost data. This knowledge was reformatted as questions, structured as a search tree of potential choices, and embedded in a web-based interface that facilitated use by engineering designers. This framework—called The GREEn Quiz, or Guidelines and Regulation for Early Design for the Environment—provides users a mean of iterative feedback of the potential environmental impact of design decisions. This method was tested using novice and more expert engineering designers, and its application was shown to increase the number of sustainable design decisions made during the conceptual redesign of an existing consumer product (a toaster), as compared to a control group (see Figure 1). More expert sustainable design engineers were able to use the method to make a wider breadth of sustainable design decisions during the conceptual design of a consumer product (see Figure 2).

Second, to ensure the feedback provided by the method more accurately reflects the potential environmental impact of a product, we sought to learn best practices from studying the environmental impact of existing consumer products. An introductory set of 37 consumer products were chosen for analysis, covering a wide array of product complexity (from one to just under 1,000 individual components). Environmental impact data was generated through the application of multiple life cycle assessment (LCA) methods, requiring product data collection and estimation. Resulting LCA metrics include CO2 emissions, water use, and electricity use over the entire lifecycle of a product, from material processing through end-of-life.

Most recently, we have developed multiple artificial neural network approaches to relate the environmental impact metrics of these products back to the database of relevant sustainable design information embedded in The GREEn Quiz. This will enable the informed weighting of feedback to users, prominently showing those design decisions that are estimated to reduce environmental impact the most. This research is ongoing.

Intellectual Merit : This project includes the collection of a cohesive set of fundamental sustainable design principles that has, for the first time, synthesized sustainable design guidelines, international design and manufacturing standards, product consumption data, consumer preference information, and product cost data, the sum of which advances sustainable design theory. These principles have been implemented in a user-friendly computational framework that allows designers to understand the potential environmental impact of a design as they make design decisions, enabling design variability with respect to sustainability. This work has led to potential partnerships with industry stakeholders, and serves as the preliminary work for an NSF CAREER proposal.
